This course had many strengths. It was taught well, and by that I mean it was extremely well-organized, the expectations and aims were very clear, and students were given copious resources to enhance their learning. The teacher genuinely wanted the students to learn and constructed the curriculum and the lesson plans to maximize student learning.  The powerpoint presentations were exceptional. The engagement and accessibility of TFs was also very impressive. It handled the many challenges of an enormous class very well.  On the other hand, this course had many weaknesses.  For one, the professor seemed to have entered the class with personal aims that were not academically oriented.  This class was designed to change the behavior and beliefs of students from position X to position Y.  In general, I believe that is not an effective intellectual tool; other classes examine position X to ask, what is a better position? What is flawed about this position? What is good about it? How should it be changed or improved? This class did not encourage students to ask better questions or try to discover their own new ways of thinking or being. Instead, the teacher "coached" us, instructing us to act a certain way, and behave a certain way, because this way, she was certain, would make us "happier." And according to science's definition of happiness, I suppose she is right. But I was hoping this class would present scientific data about strategies that improve aspects of the human condition, and then ask us more seriously what it means to be happy or lead a fulfilling life.  This class was essentially a "how-to" manual about improving your positive mood. But as some of our class readings pointed out, a "good life" is not merely being in a "good mood." Rather, a good life is a meaningful life. In this class, we rarely discussed how to increase meaning in our lives. We talked little about how to handle setbacks.  And frankly, we were unrealistic about how to implement strategies for happiness in an effective way. Additionally, I did not feel as though I walked away with a great deal more knowledge or understanding. A classmate of mine described this class as, "everything my mom has been telling me my whole life, plus some science." I agree. I can't recall feeling surprised by anything we learned in class. Finally, the strategies that we learned about, if not surprising, certainly should have been useful to students. But the gap between knowing what we should do and actually doing that (while acknowledged repeatedly), was not addressed. For our final project, we were told simply, "to do it." This theme appeared many times. We were told simply to stop caring about our grades. Look, we were told, these studies show that good grades correlate with lower happiness. And yet, the professor lecturing to us about lowering our standards for academic success would not have the opportunity to lecture, would not be standing on stage, would not hold her position as a prominent researcher, professor, and beloved head of college, if she had not gotten "good grades" when she attended Harvard. Maybe Laurie Santos did not get good grades in college. But then we should know that! More importantly, I do not believe that we must lower our personal standards of success to be happyand this was not addressed. There was little discussion about nuanced ideas and frustrations like this in the class.

The idea of the course, and the intention behind it, were good. Important, even. Ultimately, however, I felt that the course was seriously lacking in its ability to engage students (crazy, I know, considering 1,200 people took the class). The lectures frequently repeated themselves, and what bugged me the most was that instead of talking about one or two studies in depth, including some of the more controversial or interesting/complex aspects of the studies (for example, are the studies disputed [which many are, not that we spoke about that]; is there any evidence for causation rather than just correlation; etc.), Prof. Santos would move VERY QUICKLY through about 7 or 8 studies all showing the same thing; it was much less interesting than it could have been. Furthermore, at times it felt a little bit like an advice seminar, a series of twenty tips that were admittedly meaningful and important to hear, but could have been conveyed in a single lesson or two. It also felt as though Prof. Santos was too dismissive of the other side of the issue: small correlations between wealth and happiness were dismissed as "meaningless," whereas even smaller correlations between faith and happiness were treated as "small but really important." I'm sure there was legitimate reasoning behind this, but it was never explained, and overall it just added to my skepticism (which is unfortunate because I was trying really hard to engage with the material and be open minded!).

The course was a nice idea, and Prof Santos meant well, but the course was such a disappointment. Prof Santos could have presented meaningful discussions on the concept of happiness, why we pursuit it, and whether we should pursue it at all. Instead, she presented laundry lists of studies to back up superficially explained psychological phenomena, without even examining caveats or problems with the studies. Further, the pedagogy was terrible. Lectures were repetitive and badly organized, particularly in the first months of the class. The assessments involved useless rote-learning, rather than critical thinking (except for the final project, which was useful). Finally, because she only explored concepts superficially, she often mentioned highly problematic concepts/studies without mentioning their troubling implications. For example, after repeatedly telling us to pursue careers that make us happy/passionate (I.e. not finance), she told us that $75,000 was the base income threshold for happiness. Considering that most non-finance careers (non-profit, creative) have salaries under $75,000, this was a ridiculous study to bring up without exploring its implications. Rather than discussing the real meaning of this study or how we should reconcile it with other things she had taught us, she made the HIGHLY problematic claim that we shouldn't worry about this threshold because the median Yale income is $76,000. Come on, Laurie--you're a psych professor, you should know what median means. Half the people in this room DON'T have families that earn $76,000, and were sitting there feeling terrible. This is just one of the many problematic concepts she mentioned without exploring nuances (e.g. When she brought up the highly controversial Broken Windows Theory).

The strength of this course is its existence. By creating this course, issues were brought to light and to conversation that otherwise would have been ignored. Mental health on campus was discussed a great deal more, and people leaving the class were forced to converse about their thoughts on happiness, self-improvement, the quality of the course, and their own thoughts/beliefs. Professor Santos is a great lecturer in terms of her passion with the material and actual lecture slides. The final paper/project was interesting and a great way to get to engage with the material in real life and actually get to put into practice the ideas we had learned. The retirements similarly were, but the final paper was more interesting because we actually analyzed the data. 

However, I think that there were many problems with the structure of the course. One problem was that the course was incredibly easy, to a fault. Professor Santos discussed in class an experiment in which students were given problems (easy or hard) and were either graded or not graded. The students that weren't graded gravitated towards the challenging problems because they enjoyed being intellectually challenged naturally, and this diminished when they were graded. What I took from this was that students naturally enjoy being challenged. I felt that Professor Santos' course contained almost no challenge. I would have gained SO much more from a course in which my mind was stretched intellectually. I'm not sure whether the intention was to make an easy course to "relieve stress" (which contradicts her point about finding flow by doing activities that use a person's strength and challenge their ideas and conceptions), or to get more people exposed to this material (a valiant idea and goal, yet ultimately unsuccessful as very few people showed up to the lecture as the class progressed). I think this course would have benefited from more challenge and structure. The quizzes were rote memorization, and there were few other assignments. I also feel as though we were treated as though we had less intellectual capacity than we do. For example, she never explained the psych statistics (to the point that sometimes she would mention a correlation of .2 as significant, while sometimes she would mention a difference of .2 (for example 5 and 5.2) as an insignificant difference. Simply taking the time one day to explain why those values were significant vs. insignificant would have clarified the class and made the material more interesting. Additionally, SO much of the material was repeated over and over again lecture by lecture. I wish she would have trusted us to hear the material or go over it, and instead gone deeper into the material rather than repeat it so often. I think the reason she repeated material so much was that a lot of the material contradicted (as we discussed) the intuition or lies our brains feed us, but I don't think repeating it to the point of boredom was the way to allow us to hear the material more clearly.

Good points:
The course does make a lot of good points about what things do and don't matter in pursuing a happy/meaningful life, and it provides some helpful tools for understanding how our minds work and how we can motivate ourselves towards our goals. Some of the psychological biases talked about in the course also figure heavily in fields such as behavioral economics. The course does a lot to highlight how resilient people are to the disappointments of life. Most, if not all, of the major takeaways of the course are already expounded upon in religion, philosophy, literature, and common wisdom (ex: "Money doesn't make you happy"), which is good because there are major issues in how the science is presented in this course. I think one great thing that the course did though was make me more grateful about life, and I do believe the gratefulness topic made a difference in the lives of many students.

Bad points:
Professor Santos had very good intentions in creating this course, but honestly, I trust the integrity of psychology as a science less after taking this course. The findings and takeaways from the studies, though I am sure she had very good reasons for selecting the studies that she did, often were not presented in a robust, scientific manner, but unless you were someone who knew how to read scientific papers and who knew how statistics can be manipulated, this might have not been apparent. She only started putting the p values showing the significance (or not) of differences between experimental and control groups some way into the course, perhaps after people brought up the issue at office hours. The use of r values to show correlations is misleading--adding or subtracting variables will affect how large a correlation is found. Moreover, I found it troubling that some of the takeaways seemed to be presented in a way that does not account for very important nuances, with the biggest example being the "psychological immune system" topic; while it's great that in general people do not stay sad about their failures for as long as they think they will, too much indulgence in this frame of mind can lead to a dangerous complacency and not to mention years of regret (if there is a "psychological immune system", then "psychological autoimmune diseases" should also have been a topic). Another iteration of this course should look at how factors such as intent affect the results of the study.

No, I would not recommend this course. There is value to what it is trying to teach students, but in the praphrased words of Professor Santos herselfe "You won't miss too much if you take the Coursera [online course] instead". There are a lot of good topics covered in the course, and yes, it does use real science to try to understand some of the things that make people happy, but 1) you will have heard almost every major takeaway of the course if you have had exposure to religion (even if you're not religious yourself), philosophy, literature, or common wisdom (i.e. "A good night's rest is good for you")  2) this course is not the key to finding a meaningful life (nor does it try to be), and it will not provide a template for how you should live your life--that's still up to you and 3) there are some big problems with how the science is presented in this course. If you do end up taking it, make sure you understand how to read scientific papers beforehand (or learn quickly during the course) as well as have some foundation knowledge about statistics before taking this course. There are a lot of problems with how many of the findings of the studies are presented in this course--this is not to say that the findings and takeaways are all false, but let me clear, R VALUES HAVE VERY LITTLE VALUE IN DETERMINING A CAUSAL RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN CORRELATED VARIABLES (I can add many variables as I want to move an r value up or down and make the correlation between two things higher or lower). Professor Santos does stress that correlation does not equal causation, but r values are used throughout the course in a way that puts a little too much emphasis on correlation as a guiding tool for pointing out takeaways. Also, watch out for double standards in what is counted as a high correlation and what is counted as a low correlation (i.e. if r=0.10 is deemed a negligible correlation in one lecture while r=0.12 is deemed as a significant correlation in another). 
However, there are good points to the course:
The course does make a lot of good points about what things do and don't matter in pursuing a happy/meaningful life, and it provides some helpful tools for understanding how our minds work and how we can motivate ourselves towards our goals. Some of the psychological biases talked about in the course also figure heavily in fields such as behavioral economics. The course does a lot to highlight how resilient people are to the disappointments of life. Most, if not all, of the major takeaways of the course are already expounded upon in religion, philosophy, literature, and common wisdom (ex: "Money doesn't make you happy"), which is good because there are major issues in how the science is presented in this course. I think one great thing that the course did though was make me more grateful about life, and I do believe the gratefulness topic made a difference in the lives of many students.
